text: appearance: dark cola brown, fluffy light beige head lingering into a thin collar.  aroma: 	smoke, dark chocolate, vanilla, hint of brown sugar.  taste: bittersweet dark chocolate, molasses, cola, a bit of meaty smoke.  finish:  smooth palate, on the lighter side for the abv; slight sourness on the finish, maybe a hint of cherry.  notes: Drank almost like a smoked schwarzbier. Not bad. Palate was light, yes, but there was a creamy component too.  Bottle from the House of Brews in Mount Pleasant, South Carolina.
Smokier than downtown nashville brisket. Some caramel. Black pour with decent head and lacing. Bittersweet finish. Tap at brewery.

750 ml bottle into snifter, no bottle dating. Pours nearly opaque dark brown/black color with a 1-2 finger desne khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, wood smoke, nuttiness, caramel, toffee, molasses, and toasted dark bread; with lighter notes of raisin, plum, cherry, date, tobacco, leather, herbal, pepper, and roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, wood smoke, nuttiness, caramel, toffee, molasses, and toasted dark bread; with lighter notes of raisin, plum, cherry, date, tobacco, leather, herbal, pepper, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy hop and roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, wood smoke, nuttiness, caramel, toffee, molasses, toasted dark bread, light dark fruit/herbal, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with a great roasted bitter/sweet balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light dryness from hop/roast bitterness, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready/grainy, and lightly sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 9%. Overall this is a fantastic smoked Baltic porter! All around outstanding complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to sip on for the ABV. A perfectly executed style representation with the addition of cherrywood smoked malts. A really amazing offering.
Deep dark brown pour, thin white head. Smoked barley aroma. Lightly carbonated finish with a hint of hops and malts. Great selection from Yazoo.
On Tap at Yazoo Brewpub, Nashville, TN, 5.5.16. 9% abv. Black. Very smoky and woodsy aroma with hints of hickory. Velvety smokiness and roastiness in the mouth. Full body, smoky finish.

bottle. Black with small head. Theres a light smoky nature, but far more of just a roasty porter. Substantial black licorice and molasses. A bit hot. Im not crazy about the style, but found it enjoyable.

Bottle. Clear brown with a creamy tan head that lasts and laces. Aromas of roasted malt, sweet smoke, cheery, chocolate, wood, caramel and light molasses. Flavor is roasted malt, smoke, cheeey, light caramel, molasses and wood. Medium bodied, smooth with a smokey and slightly dry end.

Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is black (non-opaque, flashlight tested). Aroma is moderately malty (cocoa powder, chocolate syrup, roasted/burnt grain), with a light note of charred wood / ash. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy/creamy/watery texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic.
Well, they dont seem to have used much smoked malt, because theres not much of it in the nose. If youre looking for something Schlenkerla-level, youll be badly disappointed (its even less smoky than Alaskan Smoked Porter). But I guess a lot of American breweries fear *really* making beer smoky for fear of scaring away customers...I certainly remember my first experience with Schlenkerla being off-putting, even though I eventually came to like it quite a bit. Its basically just a boozy chocolatey beer with a little bit of burnt grain/wood character. Not bad per se, but certainly disappointing and rather dull.

"Well it was Gatlinburg in mid-July / And I just hit town and my throat was dry / I thought Id stop and have myself a brew / At an old saloon on a street of mud / There at a table, dealing stud / Sat the dirty, mangy dog that named me Sue" - Johnny Cash, "A Boy Named Sue." Life may not be easy for a beer named Sue, but it sure drinks easy. Sue is more of a malt bomb than a smoky beer. The smoke is only a savory whisper in the roasty aroma. Its only an element in the flavor profile. It adds just a touch of woody meatiness to the toasted malt, coffee, and chocolate notes. Did I say woody meatiness? That sounds weird. Ah well. Full-bodied and warm yet very mellow. If only Id gotten to taste this beer with the brisket I enjoyed hours earlier. Still, Sue is perfectly fine all by itself.

Bottle.

A- Molasses, subtle cherry, oak, subtle smoke.

A- Dark mahogany color, dark liquid, off white head.

T- Molasses, oak, dark berries, subtle smoke.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- Surprisingly not all that smokey. In all actuality, I could have done with some more smoke in it. Tons of molasses on the nose and palate. A bit of cherry/dark fruit syrup and only a hint of smoke. Really good.

750ml bottle - pours dark cola colored - thick, off-white lace - hearty cherrywood smoke in the nose, with underlying chocolate, caramelized sugar, cream, cherry skins - creamy texture - flavor is moderately bitter, lightly tart, with moderate underlying sweetness and a bit of charred maltiness - some earthy fruit skin and chocolate makes way for campfire smoke that comes mostly without drawbacks, although acidity is a little high on the tail end - the texture also becomes a little thin/watery as it warms up, and the alcohol becomes rather apparent in the flavor and nose - good, but not the home run I was hoping for, given the rep this beer used to have.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roasted malt, smoke, wood. Medium mouth, chocolate, roast, smoke, boozy finish, good.
22 oz bomber pours black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoke and grains. Taste is chocolate, smoke, fruit and grains.

Bottle shared by Eric, pours plum brown with small off white head. Smell is minerals, chocolate, dark fruit, bitter hops and Taste up front is prunes, grapes, cherry wood, and lightly smoked malt. Medium body. Really nice going for a "smoked" Porter.

Draft pour into a snifter. The beer is a darker brown with a khaki head of foam. The aroma has mild fruity sweetness with an ashy note and a chocolate cookie nuance. The taste is very sweet and has a barely noticeable smoke note. Big body and medium to lower carbonation. Chewy. Good stuff.

From notes. On tap at Bells Funvitational on September 12. The pour is a dark brown, lots of ruby shining through with a soapy tan head and a decent lace. The aroma is incredibly smoky. Youd swear it was a campfire! It almost smells like a lager also, over a porter. Strong smoked malts and not a lot else. A little chocolate maybe? The flavor is really smoky. Im drinking a campfire. The smoke dominates. Some light chocolate but its all smoked malts and maybe a hint of roasted coffee. The mouth feel is light and well carbonated. The malts linger, but the smoke fades. Aftertaste is malty and chocolate. I like the finish better than the actual beer. Too much smoke for me. Not too bad though.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2015 Sample at Funvitational. Aroma is light malt, smoke. Appearance is dark dark brown, light brown head. Taste is smoky, lots of roasted malt, coffee. Mouthfeel is thick, great carbonation. Overall, a very impressive offering.

Nashville, TN. - Craft Brewed - 22 oz bomber. Deep dark brown thick khaki nice lace. Molasses light chicolate in the aroma. Flavor is similar, some smooth smoky notes molasses dates a touch of chocolate. Thick mouthfeel.

Bottled on : 1.06.15. Brun acajou avec une tête un peu plus pâle. Une dentelle est observable. Au nez, délicats parfums de côtes levées sur le grill avec une sauce composée de cerises, de chocolat, de mélasse et, subtilement, dépices BBQ. Au goût, un mélange adéquat de cerisier qui brûle, de chocolat, de fumée sucrée, de malts rôtis sur le charbon de bois, de tabac aromatisé, de viande séchée de buf, de houblons terreux et de jambon salé. En bouche, jai limpression dun corps moyen-mince avec un pétillement actif et une texture légèrement huileuse. Une finale fumée, salée, teintée par le tabac, viandeuse, boisée, fruitée, amère. Bière (93 IBUs) très intéressante, toute en finesse, peu excessive mais complexe, plutôt facile à boire et qui cache admirablement bien son 9% dalcool.

The head is surprisingly dense and creamy considering the body isnt particularly creamy. Theres definite smoke here, but its balanced. Well done. Chocolate malt is equal to the smoke. Not overly sweet.

Savor 2015. I mentioned I really wanted to try this and Yazoo gave me a bit larger pour than normal...thanks! Nice amount of smokiness, nice mbitterness, just really a damn tasty brew. Favorite thing I had at Savor.
Bottle. Aromas are sweet chocolate, burnt wood, and smoked ham. Tastes the same but with some added vanilla and a touch of cookie dough. Top notch smoked stout.

Thanks a lot beerbluesandbbq, the Vols were the better team! Perfectly black body with a medium orange tinted tan head. Subtle sweet smoke with some pancake notes. There is also some stone fruit, like prunes. The taste is sweet raisins and smoke with bits of tobacco. I got a bit of almonds in the finish. An overall smooth and well balanced beer that is on the sweeter end for a porter. The warming booze is only an afterthought with how easy this one is to drink. A solid beer.

Pours a deep brownish black from the bomber with thin bubbly tan head that leaves moderate bubbly lace. Aroma is nice smoky wood over chocolate and vanilla. Taste of nice dark chocolate and bacon smoke, wow alcohol is well hidden, nice.

Bomber. Super roasty nose with a bunch of acrid smoke and a touch of anise. Dark brown in color much like Diet Coke. Moderate malty flavor to start with only minor smoke (which is a nice surprise given the phenol-heavy aroma), and a touch of green apple. Light body, dry finish. Not too shabby.

Bottle brought from Tennessee by my wife.

A: Black body, creme colored head. Lacing.

N: Campfire, black olive, coffee, cocoa, char, phenols, more smoke, beef jerky.

T: Smokey, bitter and then amply sweet.

M: Medium body, prickly carbonation, alcohol is hidden well.

O: A contender to Alaskan Smoked Porter. Big and burly porter all around; quote enjoyable if you like the smoke.
Bottle at the Charlottesville Tasting. Black with light tan head. Aromas of light coconut, chocolate, roast. Tastes of roast, dark chocolate, bitter roast. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
Smoke, prosciutto nose. Cola brown , medium body. Smoke, ash, wood. Medium body, easy carbonation. Robust malt bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Large format bottle dated January 27, 2015.  Black with medium light brown head. Aroma is smokey/roasty slightly dry malt, medium body, medium/light carbonation, creamy texture, and pretty good small-bubble lacing. Taste is roasty malt, chocolate, smoke, wood, some herbal hops, some coffee, and dry finish.  I would say the style is more imperial porter than smoked, but the smoke does compliment the other flavors.  For those who like dryer beers this is next level stuff.

Bottle from Suttree. Pretty much black with a resilient milky tan head. Aroma of coffee, smoke, roast, and molasses. Taste is a really nice balance of roasty bitterness and smoke. Medium bodied and creamy smooth. Excellent choice to send. Thanks Phil!

It poured a dark brown/black color with a tan head. The aroma was of burnt malts, some light cigar smoke with chocolate and a alcohol. The taste was of smoke with some vanilla and sweet malts with more alcohol.
Cherrywood on the nose, wonderful body and a subtle smokiness that lingers on the finish.
Black pour, decent sized head. Roasted malt and dark chocolate dominated by huge smoke in both aroma and taste. Thick body. Fairly good but the smoke was too much for me.
Median level smoke character, not overpowering the chocolate malt. Medium dry with perhaps a little ashy black malt and light hop bitter in the finish that sticks around. Not noticeably warm for 9%

750 ml bottle. Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours a very dark brown color with about an inch and a half tan head that stayed around a very long time. Theres also a good amount of lacing. Aroma is nice, the brew smells like smoked malt, chocolate, and a bit of coffee. It tastes like smoked malt, bittersweet and milk chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and a bit of licorice. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and coating with a good amount of carbonation. The 9% ABV is well hidden. I thought this was a good brew, if youre into smoked beers then you should probably give this one a try! $5.99 a bottle.

Dark brown with a medium, tan head and a malty sweet, coffee, smoky nose. Medium carbonation with a smooth, pleasant mouthfeel and a coffee and chicory, smoky, dark chocolate, slightly warming, dry finish.
Bottle. Deep brown with a small head. Nose is smoky. Some Cocoa and chocolate. Rich roasted nut. Taste of smoked chocolate and ham. Coffee. Not bad.
Bomber - dark pour (obviously) with a light cream head. Has a light smoke aroma and the flavor of a smoked beef stick or jerky. Medium creamy body and finish.

Surprisingly smoky aroma overpowers everything else. 

This carries over to the flavor which is as smoky as a rauchbier.

O: too smokey for my taste.

750 mL bottle supplied by WillRunForBeer - many thanks! To oversized snifter, it pours a mahogany-tinted murky light brown with which an off-white sudsy sienna head half a finger in length stood. Aromas of pine cones, cocoa nibs, smoke/ash, graham root, pecans, topsoil, spent grain, almond butter, and London yeast. Tastes the same with the addition of caramel malt, white chocolate, tar, and shiitake mushrooms.
Poured from bottle nice dark coca cola color with a lacey white head. Aromas are sweet and bread with a nice mouth feel. Not overly bitter with a slightly smoky aftertaste.
Bottle shared at my place. Pours coca cola brown with a beige head. Aroma is chocolate, licorice, smoke. Flavor follows. Caramel, chocolate, licorice, smoke.
Sample at the Beer Heads MeetUp bottle share event in October 2014. Pours a clear cola with a tan head. Flavors of licorice and a touch of smoke. Bitter roast finish.

"aroma heavy on the smoke, with chocolate and roasted malt coming out too. started nice and got better. dark brown-near black, with a chocolate colored head. body is awesome - robust and super smooth. they call it a malt bomb at 93 ibus and somehow it manages to be. milk chocolate and smoke flavor. i cant inagine how awesome this would be with ribs. lasting finish too. super well done and my new favorite TN beer! thanks Lou!
Bottle courtesy of Toby. Tennessee , check! Nice American version of the German rauch style. Dark and smoky, like sitting around a campfire.
22oz bottle thanks to Toby. Pours out black topped with a tan head. Nose roast malts chocolate coffee and plenty of that smoke. Taste is o ya lots of smoke rich malts and some more smoke.
Beer Bloggers Conference - San Diego - Dark brown in color. thin tan head. Super smoked aroma and flavor. This was a great smoked beer.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2014 Bottle courtesy of prufrock. 

Finally, my Tennessee tick!!! Thank you! 

Dark pour, obviously, nice tan head. Lovely gently smoked aroma, with the smoke prominent but not at all excessive. Sweet flavors, extremely nice. Im impressed.

Bottle, thanks to Suttree. Clear dark ruby brown with ring of khaki head. Aroma: spicy, chocolate, smoke and roast. Taste: lightly sweet up front, dry finish. Chocolate, roast/ash/smoked meat. Falls into that category of smoked beers I enjoy -- no bandaid whatsoever. Medium body, somewhat chalky texture. Overall: one of the better smoked beers Ive had, and an awesome state tick.

Pours very dark brown with large tan head out of bottle. Aroma of malt, spice, and some smoke. Very powerful smoke flavor followed by smooth maltiness. Great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black pour. Its a smoked but mixes nicely with some American stout/porter malts. Decently thick body. Probably the best smoked Ive had.

Bottle. Pours black like motor oil with creme colored head that lingers. Sweet aroma over light carbonation. Nice stout. A bit sweet but tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
yup, smoked meats just what was expected no amount of hops cuts through the smokiness. Not bad at all though good hearty beer, held up well for 9.1% 750mL

Tap at Yazoo bar in Nashville airport. Pours cola brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is chocolate and lightly roasted malts, light smoke, faint black cherries, fig, and faint vanilla. Flavor is roast malts, chocolate, faint ash, smoke, light earthy bitterness, and faint pork; smooth with a chocolate bitter finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Draft at the Nashville Airport. Pours dark brown with a fizzy, bubbly tan head. Smells like smoke and ash, sweet hickory and roasted malt. Flavor is a nice smooth balance of sweet smoke and roasted malt, light chocolate, toast, and a hint of bitter coffee. Light body and low carbonation.

On tap at BNA. A flight delay put me in need of a beer and the Yazoo Brewing station was a glorious sight! The pour was a fairly dark brown, copper hues and a thin tan head. Minimal lacing. Aromas of bold smoke, almond, sweet malt and a nice bouquet of floral hops. Taste is smoked with a nice glaze of barley, light tobacco and wood. Nicely balanced and just the assertiveness I wanted. A nice and crisp bitter finish is rounded out by more smoked wood.
Bottle at Craigs tasting. Quite dry, light smoke, chocolate, liquorice, bitter.

750 mL bottle from East End Liquors, Knoxville. Dirt cheap too. I think this was $4.99. Not factoring that into the score, but its a great price for a very nice beer if you can get this regularly. Pours a clear very dark brown color with a thin fizzy tan head. Fair head retention. Aroma of smoke, citrus, roasted malts. The taste is smoke, chocolate, roast, citrus hops, mild nuttiness. Thin-medium bodied, good balance, lingering roast and smoke. Nice beer.

Bomber from trade with springslicker. I have kind of given up on smoke beers after being mostly disappointed by them. But not this one. Perfect balance of smoke in aroma. Not overpowering. Some ash and wood with smoke. Taste is an underlying brown/porter with slight smoke and acidity. Better as it warms. Thanks jay glad I got to try this long time want
Bottle. Black with tan head. Smokey aroma, some fruity licorice. Taste is very smokey, caramel and toffee. Little sticky and bitter.
bottle at home ... deep brown ,,, thin tan lacing ... soft funky malt ... light smoke nose ,,, dark swet roast .. dark meaty smoke malt .. light fruits ... light fruits ...

2010 Vintage. 
Ar: Tar, dark chocolate, a bit of licorice - coffee, slight sherry.
Ap: Black center with brown edges, opaque - very small tan head with no retention, leaves just a thin ring and slight web.
T: Coffee and char up front, lightly sweet - mild smoke and warm, clean alcohol - beachwood smoke, dark cocoa - medium-low bitterness, slightly herbal and earthy - burnt caramel and toffee - touches of sherry oxidation.
P: Medium-full body with medium carbonation, very smooth and creamy - finish is medium-dry.
O: Delicious imperial smoked porter - the age has really melded the flavors and the oxidation is just right - still a fair amount of smoke, and it blends beautifully with the coffee, chocolate, char, and caramel flavors - the mouthfeel is wonderful, too.

Pours jet black with a decent sized tan head that left a little lacing. Aromas werent as prevalent as I thought theyd be but consisted of smoked meat and roasted malt. Flavors were more of the same along with some dark fruit--mostly cherry. Nice lasting bitterness with a medium body. A good beer with no flaws to speak of.
this was a smoked beer? meh. definitely needs to be smokier than this. ive had better.

750 mL bottle. Black in color with a large beige head. Aroma is of smoked bacon which is one of the things in life that makes me salivate any time I smell it (this beer is no exception). My mouth waters very time I take a whiff. Its sad...I know. The initial taste is like biting into a hunk of smoked honey ham...how in the hell!! (Crap! These folks have figured out my weakness!) the flavor fades to smoke, leather, and and roasted malts. This beer makes you think..."maybe my dream of liquid bacon really can come true!"...
Bottle. The look is dark, brownish black, and cashew colored head. The smell is bacon, smoked meats, smoke, roasted malts, ham, dust, and burnt. The taste is meat, malty, rich, smoke, ash, and bbq.
Pours a deep rich dark brown. Smokey aroma with a deep tan head. Subtle smokey flavor with a hint of chocolate and a smooth finish.

Black pour, wispy light brown head. Nose is big chocolate, burnt wood, some smoked lunch meats. Taste is chocolate, smoked malts, roastiness. Slightly bitter finish. Sticky mouthfeel but pretty thin and watery.
UPDATED: JAN 14, 2014 Dark. Nice amount of foam. Strong smoak taste. Alcohol is hardly noticable. A bit thin beer, not much depth.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by StFun ]. Clear dark black brown colour with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, chocolate, berry - cherries, smoke, tobacco, light peat. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate, roasted, smoke, dry, wood. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20131118]

22 oz bomber. Pours black with a decent tan head that leaves a lot of lacing. Aroma of smoked meat, bready malt, cocoa and coffee. Taste is cocoa, smoked wood, hints of coffee and toasted white bread. Long but dry finish of roasty malts and cocoa with a nice earthy hop resin in the background. Like others have said the alcohol is well hidden. There is no alcohol taste or burn Id expect with a 9%er. Full bodied, creamy texture, moderate carbonation. Excellent beer here! Exemplary of the style! Yazoo is missing the boat, theyd do great on a national level.
Had 10 oz at mellow mushroom. Good aroma and really nice smoker flavor. Did not taste boozy for a 9% beer. Very good.

While billed as a smoky beer, Sue does not have the offensive over toasted malt of many similarly described beer. Malt is rich and balanced by hops. Higher gravity and toasted malt flavor add creaminess which is especially evident in the vigorous head. There is some modest complexity and a fairly long clean finish.

Bottled May 2012

Its dark brown on black with a hourglass shaped tan silkscreen. Smells of smoke, prunes, cocoa, hersheys syrup, a little dates as well as vanilla. Flavor is smoke, leather, sweet dark malts, some dried dates and a touch of prune juice. Full bodied with a silky feel and a dry finish. Good beer, really good beer.

Poured into a snifter out of a 750ml bottle.

Pours pitch black with a velvety one finger tan head. Pretty good head retention with some nice wispy lacing

A really nice mix of roast, chocolate, and smoke on the nose. There is almost a burnt character to the nose but it is not overdone. A really nice balance there and just very rich all around.

Big shot of smoke up front in the taste along with lots of roast and velvety chocolate. I really like the cherry wood and the smokyness is very gentle and not burnt and medicinal as is sometimes the case with smoked porters. Big, chewy mouthfeel with moderate stickyness. Definitely a sipper.

Overall, I really like this beer. I am a bit fan of smoked beers anyways and this one just does it right with a great balance between the smoke and roast. Even thought this is brewed in my home state, I cant get it where I live. A shame because I would buy this on a regular basis.

bottle. black with a small brown head and good retention. dark chocolate and roasted barley aroma. flavor is lightly smoked with roast and dark chocolate notes. full and oily palate. no sign of 9%. great beer.
Great if you like smoked. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma is a smokehouse. Taste follows nose. Lots of roasted/burnt malt.
Bottle at my place with group. Pours motor oil black. Aroma is malt smoke, burnt. Taste is malt light chocolate, big smoke roast. Finish medium. Very interesting, unique and well crafted beer.

Bottle shared by Chaney. Thank you Brandon.

The beer is a deep, dark mahogany, appearing black in low light. Opaque. Atop the beer is a half inch of oily beige head. The aroma offers chocolate, roast, licorice, molasses, smoke. Smoke and roast with lovely chocolates. Fabulous aroma and flavor. Medium bodied and a bit chewy, coating the palate. Smooth and creamy with fairly low carbonation. A terrific beer and superb example of a porter.
Picked up a bottle in Chattanooga. Pours black with light brown head. Sole chocolate and roast. Smoke. I understand this beer is to style. But I'm not a fan of the style.
Big bottle in a tulip. Pours black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of smoked and roasted malts, some dough, and some light hops. Flavor the same. Average texture. A pretty good beer.
Pours a black color with a tan head and Nice lacing. Aroma is nice and malty. Taste is smoky and very nice.

750ml bottle, shared by caterwaul. Black color. Nice thin light brown head. Good spread of dotty lace. Bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter carbonation. Lightly dry in the finish. Awesome level of smoke to this. Nice lighter chocolate, good robust lightly dark fruity flavors. Moderate roast. Good moderate to bigger bitter taste, light sweet. Nothing over the top or gimmicky about this, its all in balance, for me... But its the perfect amount of everything. Smoke, chocolate, roast.. Very well-balanced, but big, imperial smoked porter. Good wood and fruity notes (light earthy cherry flavors)

Bottle from Riverside Wine. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. I get mostly chocolate roast on the tongue and nose. Im not getting much smokiness. Finish lingers a bit. Alcohol is well hidden but does have a nice warming quality.

This beer did not thrill me in the least. Its a good beer, but not a great beer. Had on tap in Nashville and all around me people were raving about it.....but my friend and I thought it average. A dark brown pour with huge aromas of smoked wood, roasted malt, and dark fruit. Flavour was too much smoke and not enough malt and hops for me.

651mL thanks to t0rin0 and Womencantsail via Travlr for my wedding reception. Again, not sure if it really is that good or I was just in a great mood, but at least six of my friends tried this with me and loved it. Black pour with serious carbonation. Big mocha head. Good retention. Smoked character here is unique in that it is incredibly savory like barbecue brisket or ribs rather than sometimes a sweet cherry note common in rauchbier. Taste is clean, mild lactic, heavy coffee and roast, grilled steak and Texas barbecue savory character abounds. Really fantastic.
Bottle courtesy of t0rin0, opened at the GT2-biggirlpanties wedding. My favorite of the wedding. Rich, dark, roasty toasted cocoa. Deserves its reputation.
Sweet and alcoholic. I expected a bit more smoke, but the mildness of this beer, its vanilla notes and roasted flavor are nice. Josh brought this back with him from Mississippi.

22 ounce bottle poured black with aromas of light smoke, ash, earth, and roast.  Flabors are roast wih some light ash and smoke.  A toich of earth in the aftertaste, not much smoke but a solid beer overall.
Bottle. Pours black, nice smoky aroma. Some chocolate, lots of smoke on the tongue. Taste like summer campfires. Really pretty good. I like smoked beers.

Bottle. Picked it up from the grocery store the other day but I think it says its a 2011 bottle? Pours a deep brown with a persistent pillow of light tan head. Aroma is woody, sweet, lightly smoky, a bit of vanilla, and spice. Taste is sweet smoke, vanilla, a dry wood finish. The taste really lasts. Nice and warming.

Deep dark brown pour with a thick mocha head.  Nose is of smoke and coffee.  Taste is smoked malt with a rich roasty awesomeness.  Body is silky.  Finish is good smoke that doesnt overpower.  Very solid beer.

Bottle from a trade, can't read date. Pours dark opaque brown with a tall dark kahki brown head. Aroma of coffee, smoke, booze, and lots of toasty roasty malt. Big smoke flavor and roasted malts dominate. A but of coffee in the background and not too much bitterness. Blows Stone's versin out if the water. Medium mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Goes down easy but certainly not a light beer. Pretty good.

650ml bottle from trade with Jzzbasman. Thanks Monte. Pours a dark brown-blackish color with a small beige head that has good retention. The aroma is big and bold with a smoked aroma that conjures up memories of smoked sausage and smoked brisket. The flavor is more of the same, lots of smoky goodness with smoked meats, some plums, cola, a bit of burnt toast and very bitter roasted walnuts. The palate is full and silky smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long and bitter-smokey with a bit of acidity. Overall: Ive waited a long time to try this and it did not disappoint me. This is definitely a smoked beer for smoke lovers, all other beware.

Bottle (thanks to AlexFields for this bonus beer)...  Poured dark black with a easy forming, khaki head.  Nose had some smoke on it.  This really hit you with smoke with a nice cocoa and coffee undertone for dimension.  Low roast on the malt which rally allowed the smoke to shine like a campfire.  If you like smoky beers this will hit the spot.  Stay away if you dont care for them.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours deep cola with a bubbly tan head. Nose is dry campfire smoke, tobacco, and some dark sweet malt. Taste is about the same, with dry smoke, a bit of bold malt, and some sticky sweetness. A little watery in the mouth.

Pour is viscous and dark with a thin tan head. Aroma is of burnt malts, light cigar smoke, chocolate, and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is heavy on the smoke with a finish of sweet malts and booze. Notes of vanilla, dry earth.

On draught at Taco Mamacita. Brownish-black pour with a medium thin tan head that dissipates slowly. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of smoked malt and chocolate. Medium to full body with a mildly smoky character and flavors of roasted coffee, malt and a bit of dark fruit. The finish is charred malt and coffee. Above average, one of the better Yazoo beers I have tried.
Great looking dark beer with tan head.  Sweet smoked smell.  Good balanced flavor with little bitterness bite at end.  Not near as heavy as it looks.

On tap at Keg and Barrel. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of smoke, smokey meats, roasted malt. Flavor is smoky and meaty up front, with some peat. Quite smoky and good too, with a strong malt backbone.
7/4/7/4/15 (3.7/5)

25oz bottle. Pours a very dark brown with almost no head. Aroma is a really deep smoke that I havent experienced in other smokey beers. I assume the cherry wood is creating this different experience. The flavor is plenty of roasted malt and some sweetness. The finish however is all smoke. I dont really detect the hop presence, unless the bitterness is being masked by the smoke. Really interesting beer.
Beautiful in color, taste, aroma, and overall impression. Nicely done drank at suttrees in knoxville tn
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Nice smoked offering. Smoke flavor is pleasant but not overpowering. Coffee and chocolate round this one out well.

Bottle from Highland Package in Birmingham. Bottled on date is... blank. Pours black with a think light tan head. Nose is smoky at first, with wood notes... but the beer opens up to show more complex chocolate and dark fruits. Lovely beer.

Bottled on Date: Nov 01 2012. 750 ml bottle into a DFH signature glass. Thanks to sommersb for this one! Ill preface this by saying I HATED this beer the first time I tried it about two years ago. Giving it another go with a proper review.

A - Pours a pitch black body that lets almost zero light through. Massive mocha head that sticks around for a long time. Gobs of sticky lacing and lasting retention. Pretty beer for sure.

S - Well. Smoke. Smoke and lots of it. It isnt artificial or over the top, it oddly has layers. Starts off a bit sweet and salty and finishes with a bit of cinnamon spice. Maybe a touch of coffee and chocolate, but those are very secondary. Long lasting char burn.

T - Opens up with soft smoke. Quickly washed away by bitter coffee beans and some milk chocolate. The finish returns to that smoky wood that works nicely against the mineral quality of the porter base. Finishes clean without giving the impression of chewing on a piece of charcoal. 

M - Medium bodied with ample carbonation. Pretty spot on for a porter.

O - Well Im a changed man. From drain pour to somewhat impressed, this is a very solid smoked porter. The aroma is big and smokey but the flavor itself is clean, light, and the smoke never overwhelms. I figured a beer like this in a large format is a terrible idea. Nope, it totally works.
We had this beer at the 2013 Tops of the Hops in Biloxi, MS. It was malty and good.

Poured from a 22 oz bomber. Deep, dark black color with an light tan head that leaves a small amount of lacing. Aroma of smoke. Unbelievable. Its a smokey, hickory type smell. Smells like I am outside cooking on the grill. I dont detect anything but the smoke. Taste is somewhat smokey but smoother than I expected. Leaves a little burn and bitter taste. I dont, in general, like smoked beers, but this is supposed to be one of the best beers in Tennessee (where I live). Turns out to be better than I expected, but still not a fan of the smokiness.

22 oz bomber (compliments of Sutree) poured into a snifter. Pitch black pour with a nice brown head which quickly disappears and leaves spotty, bubbles of lacing. Deep, deep dark malt roast with a just hint of smoke. Wonderful medium body. Big malty punch in the mouth followed by a lingering light campfire taste, not overpowering at all. Smoked jerky comes to mind. Smooth finish with peat and coffee grounds on the back of the tongue.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Smoke, sour milk and chocolate malt aroma.  Dark black-brown with minimal head.  Lactic smoky chocolate malt and moderately bitter herbal hops flavor.  Nice body.  Very good.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma is a meaty smokiness, dark fruits (raisins, cherry) and wood.  The flavor has a meaty smokiness, chocolate, dark fruits, and wood.  Medium plus body and smooth.

Bottle.Mild to moderate smoky malt, sweet chocolate, prune aroma.  Black with a moderate brown head, with some nice lacing. Wood smoked meat, roasty chocolate malt, and a little ashy  flavor.  Full body, soft carbonation, slightly dry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2013 Roasty, smokey, hearty, and absolutely delicious. For a style I utterly despise, Im pleased to say that I love Sue. Wish I could drink this more often. 

Original: Smoked beers are my least favorite style *by far*, yet the hearty malts in Sue balance nicely with the mild smokeyness to yield an enjoyable drink.  Cant think of a better beer to pair with BBQ.  Recommended, even if you despise rauchbier like I do.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Fantastic beer from my hometown of Nashville, deep, dark, sensual, and delicious.... Enjoy as often as possible folks

Bottle. Pours nearly pitch black with a medium brown head that dissipates quickly with some lacing. Aroma is smoky dark roasted malts, bacon, coffee, wood, very interesting. Flavor is much the same, strong smokiness from start to finish, lightly sweet and lightly bitter with some acidity. Smoky, tongue coating finish. Light to medium body. Very interesting, but too one dimensional to compete with the best.

Bottle thanks to Ernesto. (I dislike smoked beers so take that in mind as I didnt rate this to style, just to my taste.) Pours a thick dark brown with a small light brown head. Aroma is antiseptic band aid all the way. Some dry smoked jerky but then more band aid. Taste is not as pronounced smoke but a very chocolate sweet, bitter, mess. Nothing in this beer is something I could do again. Im sure it is the smoke that is doing this but I really am not a fan of this one, or apparently, the style.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
12 oz, 64 degrees F in a snifter.

A - Pours black and a 2 finger tan head. 

S - smoked malts and chocolate. Hint of raisins.

T - Campfire throughout. Hint of dark fruits, some sweetness but its a smoked beer UGH. not my cup of tea. Its still pretty balanced.

M - Heavy body, medium carbonation

O - I wasnt expecting much from this. I like the cherry but still..not my cup of tea.

Big thanks to grownfool for sending me this as part of a recent trade. This was definitely smoky and I hate to say this but there is something about rauch/smoked beers that is similar to wet dog! Cheap beef jerky too. Band aids almost. The flavor is a little bit of chocolate then some smoky, rubbery flavors. Im sorry but I cannot fuck with smoked beers (yet).

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-05-2010 04:59:11
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle shared by Folty at Darkness Day 2012 - thanks! Dark brown pour with minimal head. Light smoke and roast aroma and taste. Solid.
Bottle via trade from a while back. Dark brown pour with some head. Roasted malt and some smoke in aroma and taste.

Big bottle.  Pour is pretty much black wth a full light brown head. Does not look overly viscous.  Aroma is mostly clean roasted malt up front with hints of toasted brown sugar malt and light smoke.  The smoke is in the background for sure.  Flavor is smooth roasted malt with hints of tobacco and light smoke. Very smooth and creamy.  Smoke is present but not overwhelming. Very easy to drink and quite tasty. Better than expected.
Bomber to Bottle to taster (thanks Bunker). Looks solid; pitch black with beige lacing. Smells smoky and malty. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel.
Black with tan head.  Aroma is all smoke.  Taste is sweet, not very roasty or acidic.  Smoke is in the aftertaste.  Pretty thick for a porter.  Nice beer.

Pours black ish with off white head. Smell is light smoke and roasted grain. The taste is smooth with a very present light smokey flavor. The porter is true to style with a light earthy fruitiness under the roasted grain and light smoke. Lighter body smoothness but lots of rich flavor. Very pleasant overall really strong for style.

Bottle at Mahogany bar in my home town. Kinda dark inside so its hard to see but here it goes. Pours cola color with no head. Intense smoke flavor with mal back one. Mouthfeel is thin. There is a lot of smoke flavor in this beer. Alcohol is well hidden. Glad to see mississippi has this

Thanks to barzigkin for sharing this bottle. This has been on my wants list for several years. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma has a ton of smoke, as well as some roasted malt. The flavor is very similar. I get a ton of meaty, BBQ smoke up front. I also get some chocolate and a hint of roasted malt, but this is definitely all about the smoke - and the smoke is very well done. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice smoked beer that didnt disappoint.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a long lasting creamy tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, a bit of cocoa, light roast and some bits of smoke and coffee. Flavor starts with some chocolate and smoke quickly picking up some hints of licorice, coffee and dark fruit, finishing sweet and creamy but with notes of earthy hop bitterness. Medium full body and a soft carbonation. Very good smokey robust porter.

Bottle... Clear dark brown ale with dirty orange highlights and a small, creamy, white head. The aroma is an eclectic collection of smoked meat, mocha and caramel. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and tickling carbonation. Lots of espresso noted in the flavor - carbonic, bitter and burnt. Finishes bitter and flat-out scorched.

12oz bottle from Santa. Pours very dark brown with tan head. Aromas of smoke, chocolate, and roasted malts. Flavors of roasted malts, some smoke, light hop bitterness, and some chocolate. Body is perfect for style. Perfect campfire beer. Cant believe this is 9.1% could have drank this all night.
Pours a dark brown color. Slightly smoky aroma and coffee notes.  Tasty dark roasted coffee flavors.  Overall, not bad... Thanks to Mora2000 for sharing!

Nice beer.  Very similar to Fore Smoked from Dark Horse (but a bit thinner), 9.1% is very well integrated and hidden, great body for that, maybe even too attenuated, fluffy carb, smoke is light, bacon chocolate (I have some smoked ham chocolate brittle from Nashville here too! thats basically exactly what it tastes like), flavors are toned down, and seemingly too homogenized, could use a bit more pop.  Very nice, drinkable, beer here.

Poured into a shaker from the bottle.  The color is deep black with tan head that dissipates quickly with nice lacing.  The nose is full of charred wood, heavily roasted malts; all smokiness really.  The taste is again of char, roasted meat sweetness with almost no semblence of the 9% ABV (which gets on you later in the beer).  The mouthfeel is full, a little creamy, minimal carbonation.  Overall, the smoke just owns this beer; very enjoyable, but its just a touch heavy on the smoke.

Bottle poured a translucent dark reddish brown nearly black with a lasting creamy brown head. Aromas of smoke,roasted malt, bakers cocoa, light coffe and light dark fruit. Palate was medium to full bodied and smoth. Flavors of roasted malt, smoke, bitter chocolate, light dark fruit and a hint of coffee with a smooth lingering smokey roasty finish.
Bottle. Pours black no head. Aroma of smoke and roast malt. Taste is sweet Smokey malt

Bottle sent to me by jbrana in a recent trade.  Thanks Justin!   Brown with a small tan head, some lace, little legs.  Nose shows some milk chocolate, smoke, a little wood, roast.  Solid flavor, a touch sweeter and less smokey than Id like it to be, but it doesnt have any major flaws and drinks pretty nice. Soft carbonation, medium bodied, with a fairly balanced sweet, bitter, smoke finish.  More of a porter with some notes of smoke than a smoke beer in my opinion.

Thanks Turdferguson.  Pours an inky black with two fingers of creamy coffee tan head.  Nose is nice and roasty with lots of smoked and cured meat notes. Light dextrinous sweetness.  Medium body with a low carbonation and nice medium bitterness.  Meaty and roasty flavor,  yum. Lightly sweet with a zesty bitterness to balance it all out.

Man, this smoked porter makes for a nice pint, particularly since my previous beer was so absolutely fucking dreadful.  Yazoo SUE smacks you like a burning brick, but I mean that in the nicest possible way.  The initial mocha-tinged sweetness soon grows a mean hoppy growl, but the real shindig doesnt start until the thick, smoky ass shows up, like a newly-divorced MILF strolling into a redneck bar.  The smoke never gets crazy, though, rather choosing the underline everything with a curious but lovely extra layer.  Delicious.

(12oz bottle).  Pours pitch blakc with an espresso head.  Aroma is savory smoke, bacon, chocolate.  Taste is sweet with more savory smoke and some bitterness.  Thinner bodied and oily. Finish is dry and bitter.  This is an excellent beer and one that, in my opinion, would be even better if it werent so hoppy.  Its pretty damn good though.

Bottle pours black with light tan head.  Aromas are smoke, peat, bacon, and some sweetness.  Tastes are roasted malt, bacon, smoke, and some happiness in the finish.  Overall, a pretty tasty one but definitely not for the smoke hater.

12oz., bottled Jan. 2011.  Aroma of dark, almost burnt sweetness, toffee, cocoa and earthiness, with very faint raisin and plenty of woody smoke and coffeeish malt roast.  Utterly black in color with a very fine, subsiding head.  Flavor profile is surprisingly complex, with strong, dark, roasty, sweet and smoky malts providing the strongest aspects, along with suggestions of black cherry, dark dried fruits, a moderate degree of spicy hop flavor and bitterness that appears towards the finish.  Palate is very low in effervescence, thick, chewy and mildly warming, with a richly full body.  This is excellent, just the right amount of smoke for my preferences; a very well-done rendition.  Cheers to Gregis for hooking me up with the bottle some months back.

Pours a brown black opaque color.  The taste is richer and creamyer then I anticipated.  The smokeyness is nice but not as apparent as I had hoped for a beer classified as a smoked beer.  This is more an imperial porter with some light smokey notes.
Thanks to illismitty, this is a tasty smoked milk type stout. No hops really noticeable. Pretty tasty

Bottles been sitting for a while. Dark thick pour. Aroma has smoked malts, some hints of ash and woody smoke. Not my thing. The flavor has smoke, some faint sweetness and roasted malts, mild cocoa and coffee and a fiant bitterness. Smoke lingers, hard for me to find a smoke beer I love.
Bottle. Pours black, medium thin tan head. Smoked wood, bbq aroma. Mild sweet flavor, balanced hop (and smokey) finish. Enjoyable tasty brew.
Good beer. Very smokey in the flavor and I am loving all the malty mouth full goodness of this brew.

Smelling some smoke and black olives in this... Seriously olives, WTF? Geez this is completely different than I expected. It almost is meaty. I read the description after I smelled the olive and I agree that it is like a pizza. Mildly smokey put the robust porter flavor is still there and some malt. the carbonation is perfect and the acidicy is as well. I like this beer a lot, very interesting as I havent had many this style. Alcohol is definitely there though. Nice beer and glad to knock this one off the list.
Nice roasty, dark flavors and Good body. Might be a little thick for a "porter" but doesnt detract from overall. Smokiness is a bit ashy. Seems well-balanced but leaves a little something behind.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 From the 3/2012 3R6P tasting. +++Sampled from a 12 brown bottle this beer poured thick and black with a small brown head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was strong smoke, wood, back on and soot. The flavor was soot, wood and faint bacon. The finish was long and sooty. Medium body. Too sooty for my taste.

Aroma of chocolate, hot caramel, campfire, (dough?) and aromatic hops. Appearance is black with frothy mocha head. The flavor is smokey and chocolate intensive, but with some coffee and slight peat in the finish. Palate is creamy with some bubbles. Pretty awesome.

Nice smokiness in the nose. Pour is dark dark brown--almost black. Head is a very pale, fizzy caramel. Tastes like it smells: smoky with a sweetness at the end. Mouthfeel is a bit thin and fizzy, but seems appropriate for the style.

Draught in Chattanooga Mellow Mushroom:  This was served in a 10 oz. goblet that was unfortunately frosted (BOO!).  It pours an opaque dark brown.   There was a wisp of a tan head on it that left some lacing.  Chocolate and some roasty notes to the nose.  Also a hint of earthy hops.  The taste is good.  Fairly full bodied.  Chocolate malt, caramel, some roastiness.  Minimal sweetness:  lots of hops in here to balance it nicely.  Very Good!

12oz bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.
Near black pour with some brown head.  Nice smoky, roasted, chocolate aroma - smoke aroma and taste is near perfect and does not overpower.  Excellent smoked brew, one of the best Ive had.
Got this one in a trade a while back.  Dark brown with brown tints.  Nose is light campfire and red wine.  Taste is huge.  Big sweet malt to deep roasty smoke.  Very nice.
12 ounce bottle from a friend.  Pours almost black with a thick tan head.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Taste is chocolate, smoke, burnt malt, and caramel.  Very nice!

Bottled on Sep. 19, 2011
Tasted on 1/21/12 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Midtown.  Pours an opaque, nearly black cola brown with an average tan head that slowly recedes to rocky lace.  The nose is nicely smoked, not overwhelming, with some caramel, molasses, tons of chocolate, ranging from milk to dark, with some light bitterness.  The flavor is lightly sweet molasses, caramel, and milk chocolate up front, moving to the more roasted dark and smokey notes of dark chocolate, coffee, and toasted cocoa nibs.  The body is full and creamy with average carbonation and a very long, lightly bitter nicely smoked coffee, dark chocolate, and molasses finish.

A beer named Sue!  This has a medium-brown colored, bubbly head thats airy and fizzes out fast atop an extremely dark brown-colored body, almost black, with some transparency thats hard to see unless you look at the edges - otherwise a pretty solid and dark color.  The bartender said this was her favorite, but you have to like smoked beers.  Lucky for me.  The aroma is a good tell sign of a good smoked beer in my opinion.  This one has an almost barbeque/jerky/smoked meat aroma.  Very delectable and good.  Definitely the best Ive had so far from Yazoo.  Not very often can you have all of the beers from an obscure brewery from half a country away.  Flavor is not as inviting as the aroma, though.  Its a little tame for the heft of the aroma.  Although it still showcases what this beer is made of.  Its very dense and very smoky in the mouth.  The dense smokiness and slight roasted bitterness carries through to the finish very well, and in a very bitter way.  For a smoked beer its very good (esp for an American smoked).  Almost up to par with an authentic Rauchbier, but on the lighter end.  A little sweetness carries through to the finish as well due to whats left behind on your tongue and lips after the smoke and roast decimates your mouth.  Im very impressed!

Pour is deep deep brown to black. Head is prominent but fades to a film in a minute. Nose is super woody barrels, smoked meats, campfire, caramel malts and coffee. Flavor is sweet smokey malts, wood fires, medium sweet smokey finish. full body. rich and glorious. This one really makes the cherrywood malts stand out.

Not a big nose, but great chocolate and smoke tastes. Good head. A little hint of spice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
pitch black pour with a khaki head.  nose is smoke, meat, rye, and grain.  excellent on the palate, wow heavy smoke, bbq all the way around.  nice smoked finish.

12oz bottle - Herring Creek beer tasting 

First, a HUGE thank you to my southern brother, bluesandbarbq, for sending me this wonderful brew. Yazoo was all over this one when they made it, and the proof is in the beer. The beer pour out a mahogany brown/blackish body with a beige 1/2" cap. Aroma is smoke, tar, a litte leather, rosted malts and charred fruit. Flavor steers more towards the roasted malts, than smokey malts, and its almost stout-like with the flavor. Woody, roasty, smokey, lightly figgy, light bitterness with bit of a twangy/alcoholic finish. Definitely blurs the lines in my mind between a smoked ale/porter/stout. Love when beers do that.

Name: Sue
Date: May 28, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Bhalter Summersalter
Appearance: clear brown, wispy beige head, streaks of lace
Aroma: smokey aroma, chocolate, just a hint of sweetness
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, lots of smoke, drying earthyness
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

Pours a thick black with a dark, tan head. The aroma is of burnt malt, espresso and black toast. The taste is fairly dry, with some sweet caramel notes on the back-end, but otherwise bitter, burnt malt is the prevalent taste note. Pretty good beer, and definitely one of the better high-ABV stouts, but nothing Id want to drink regularly.
Old note from a smoke tasting with drowland and co.  Light smoke and cocoa aroma.  Tastes are roasty smoke, chocolate, vanilla and raisin.  Pretty good.
Nice pour with thin head that clung to the glass well.  Heavy alcohol on the nose with a powerful backbone of smoke.  Flavor is heavy with smoke and sweet malt.

On tap at Flying Saucer, Memphis.  Thick, unfiltered amber black.  Steady, impressive rusty beige head.  Creamy thick yeasty body.  Rich, full body.  The smoke is really well incorporated, merging well with the big chocolate and mellow warming alcohol tones.  Quite enjoyable, well done.

12oz Bottle. Thanks for sharing, Sean! This is damn, damn good beer. Nice mingled hoppy and Smoke aroma. I think the smoke is up there, but, for my tastes, could definitely be notched up. That said, this is a very well structured and integrated beer, with fine control of the elements that combine to make it a rich, complex, and velvety concoction. I appreciate the mingling of hops and smoke.

12oz bottle courtesy of jzzbassman. Pours dark brown/black with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, caramel, salted smoke meat, and a smokey wood fire. Smoke is just super potent, in a good way, with underlying chocolate, coffee, and molasses. A really clean taste all the way round no loose ends really nice balance. Really enjoyable.
Bottled. A dark red-brown beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, roasted malt, soy sauce, and wood. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, roasted malt, wood, and soy sauce.

12 oz bottle got in a trade from Mr.  Bishop in Tenn.  Opened inSan Diego into a pint.  Looks very black with light brown sticky head.  smells very smokey with some coffee.  Tastes Deep dark and brown with sour coffee and roasty.  There is quite a bit of bitterness on the front of the palate.  decently thick on the palate.  Overall 8.5 of 10

(12oz bottled November thanks to ericandersnavy) espresso brown with ruby highlights. Nose of rich chocolate, smoke, and cream, really nice! Taste of cream, medium sweetness, light smoky, roasty, and absolutely delicious. Great linger, touch of smoke. One of the best smoked beers I have ever had.

A: Pours a very dark brown color with a finger of mocha colored head that has nice retention.

S: Quite smokey.  A touch of salt along with the burnt wood and smoke.  Lots of roasted malt with a hint of cocoa.  Theres a light fruitiness to the aroma as well, which I wasnt anticipating.

T: Sweet toffee and dark fruits up front before the smoke takes over.  Lots of smoke, wood, and a light saltiness.  A bit of nuttiness, mostly almonds, with mild chocolate flavors.

M: Medium bodied with a medium to high carbonation.

O: Never really a fan of smoked beers, but this one adds a nice little fruitiness.

Bottle from Midtown Wine and Spirits in Nashville. Pours jet black with a khaki head that collapses to a thin skin. The nose is a pleasant, sweet, smoky, dark roasted malt with cocoa and cherry undertones (beneath the smoke). This is probably the best nose Ive ever encountered from a smoked beer. I would be content to just draw off the snifter and never bother to actually drink the beer. Fairly light-bodied for a 9.1% beer, the mouthfeel is lightly grainy with a dry, mildly tart and smoky finish. The flavor is of sweet, fruity and smoky dark roasted malt with a woody (versus the typical "meaty") smoke lingering well beyond the swallow. This is a beer fully worthy of its reputation. If you like this style, you owe it to yourself to find and try this beer. Very nice.
Dark pour with a with a fluffy tan head and drippy lace. Aroma is smoked malts. Chocolate and smoke. I wasnt expecting much from this but is was really solid stuff

tasting on 8/20/11. black pour with a light tan head.  smoke / roast nose - really nice level of smoke on this one.  medium body, sweet, smoke, citrus.  sweet light bitter finish with lingering smoke.

Rich, smoky aroma has coffee, molasses, nutty and yeasty notes. It pours an opaque sable with a thick and fluffy light tan head. Flavor has a firm roast coffee tone as well as nutty, caramel and semi-sweet chocolate notes and a hint of licorice. Full-bodied texture is smooth as almond milk and only slightly fizzy. Finish is smoky with chocolate and nutty tones, and the tingle is slight and not persistent. However, that is the beers weakest aspect, and does not make it any less enjoyable. If you are a stout/porter fan, look for it.

Received in trade from GPHarris, thanks for the opportunity.
Pours a dark brown/black color with a thinnish tan head that quickly dissipates to a ring. Smells of roasted campfire mixed with a bit of chocolate and caramel. Smell is really malty sweet with hints of cherry, plum, and a touch of alcohol. Thick chewy mouthfeel with a full body and very light carbonation. Taste is caramel and fruit right up front before the smoked malt takes over. A bit of earthy hop bite comes in then some alcohol followed by a long lingering roasted finish with hints of smokey phenol. Wow this one was good! I love it when something flys in under the radar and wows me.

Small light brown head with fair retention and little lacing. Almost black in color. Roasty, smokey, little phenols, wood. Medium bodied, gentle carbonation, oily on the palate. Rich, chocolatey smokyness, dry malts, caramel, roast and some smoked meaty notes as well. Finish is dry, long and fairly rich. Props to jzzbassman for the bottle! Thanks dude!

Bottle pours a deep brown and opaque body with a two finger tan head. Good retention and patchy lacing. Aroma of campfire smoke, roasted coffee beans, and dark chocolate. Creamy carbonation supports a slightly fuller than medium body. Taste has elements of smoked meats, almost like good barbecue, earthy hops, campfire smoke, dark chocolate, and roasted coffee. Reminds me of the smoked beers from Bamberg. Best Tennessee beer Ive ever tasted by a longshot.

On tap at the Mellow Mushroom. Pours pitch black with a little tan head. The aroma is mellow chocolate and coffee, licorice, and a faint but distinct smoky note, like salted meat or a cook fire. The flavor is very sweet up front, with the smoke adding a bitterness and spiciness to the finish. The palate is light to medium, smooth and clean. Overall, a subdued smoked beer, and a nice porter.

Pours black, smoke and grease aromas.  Not as thick, but certainly as smokey and boozy as can be expected.  Understated carbonation.  Dangerously easy drinking, fairly one dimensional, a little roast and mollasses and complex smoke (cherry wood).  Alcohol warming.Bottle from Tim S IP.

Huge thanks to Photekut for sending me a couple of bottles of this beer. You are a true Beer Advocate!

Pours a deep, dark chestnut brown color that appears pitch black and completely opaque in the glass with a one finger frothy light beige head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Spotty lacing left behind.

Smokey, roasted malt aroma with hints of burnt toast, charcoal, BBQ, bacon and burnt wood. Underneath the smoked malt there are hints of chocolate, caramel, oatmeal and nut as well as some earthy hops. Smells nice ans smokey without being one dimensional with the chocolate notes really standing out.

Medium boded, on the fuller end with a nice toasted/smokey character that lingers throughout over the bitter dark malt notes and earthy hops into a slightly sweet, yet dry, finish. Roasty and smokey up front with hints of charcoal and hickory smoked BBQ which lingers long into the aftertaste. Slightly burnt tasting but the sweet notes and hop bitterness prevent it from becoming acrid and one dimensional. Underneath the smoke there is a nice bittersweet dark chocolate malt character along with hints of toffee, oatmeal and coffee bean. The hops compliment the dark chocolate malt, adding a nice dry, earthy bitterness toward the end of the palate. Very smokey but still complex and flavorful. One of the better smoked beers Ive had in a while. Recommended!

This poured a darker brown color almost black, with a small beige head. Aroma was almost all liquid bacon, just smoke peaty, meat, and some leeather too. Flavor was a bit subdued compared to the aroma, but still very nice meaty smokey flavors. Great beer.

Bottle shared by Beerman6686 at RBSG. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Smoked malty aroma, with peat and a light sweetness. The flavor is smokey, peaty, and burnt, with leather, a light sweetness, and a hint of bacon. Good stuff.

At SAVOR. Poured a dark color with a small white head. Aroma was dark fruits, smoke, caramel notes. Flavor was first and foremost smoke, dark caramels, chocolate notes. Interesting brew. Really 9.1%? Didnt seem that high, but could have just been well masked.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a little head and weak aromas at first (the bar kept it way too cold and poured into a frozen glass) but they get better as it warms.  Peat, chocolate and maybe cherry in the nose.  Flavor is even better... its like a really nice light imperial stout with black cherries, chocolate and peat, maybe a little light on the palate, but darn flavorful.

text: Poured from a 12oz bottle from BastionShaw.  Pours nearly black with tan head.  Nose is tons of smokiness, some chocolate.  Taste follows the nose.  Sweet, smokey and really tasty.

Pours dark black with off white head, aroma has notes of dark fruit, caramel, smoke, some chocolate.  Taste is big meaty and salty chocolate, caramel and dark fruit notes compliment with some nice roast.  Delicious, balanced, but not overly complex.
On tap as part of this past weekends fest.  Not sure Id really call it a smoked, I just thought it was a porter/stout.  Pretty good, pretty sweet.  A bit of a thin mouthfeel, but easy to drink.

Draft. Poured clear ruby color with an average creamy light brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt and smoke aroma. Medium to full body with an oily texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced smoke sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2012 New rating: Re rated at the 2012 RB Pgh May tasting.much better! the old rating I gave it a 2.3  this time its much better in aroma and flavor. Old rating:Courtesy of lithy, nice guy.  Im afraid that I am not qualitfied to rate this what I thought to be an imperial stout.  Big choco dark pour with a tan head that fades.  Imp stout or dry stout aroma of possibly roasted chocolate. Now that I know its smoked its easier to overlook the impy stout character of this stuff.  Strong beefy punch in the nose. Same on the finish, quite a smokey experience. Weww.  What an experience. This is a kick ass beer, if you are into impy stouts and big stouts, give this a try.  My first from yazoo and my first from tennessee, thanks justin.
